text:
I agree with you <@UJJFDTN8G>, finding the best resources at a budget requires a whole lot of hard work. 

If I may ask, how were you able to successfully juggle multiple hats? Was there a process?

elements.text: I agree with you
, finding the best resources at a budget requires a whole lot of hard work.
If I may ask, how were you able to successfully juggle multiple hats? Was there a process?

text: I think this style of working suited me. I work quickly and I like learning new things. I could write a new post in 2 hours. Then work on *how to make it better, optimise for SEO, find places to share it, add in CTAs, etc* much later. I'd do this by googling everything. I was a writer, not a marketer, so there was  A LOT  of googling.

text:
I documented its failings and successes here, if of interest: <https://www.digital-freelancer.org/blog/successes-failures-startups-content-marketing>

I don't think there's any downside to having them as separate domains (despite the 100s of LinkedIn messages I get telling me otherwise).

text: Good morning! Wanted to get some insight from fellow marketers on something. We've spent the past few months producing the first season of a new podcast and developed a campaign to coincide with its launch, which was scheduled for today. We decided over the weekend to pull the plug for the time being, as we felt it would have seemed tone deaf and trivial after the events of this weekend. We're trying to figure out the right way to approach it now. I'm curious to hear how others are handling similar situations this week.

elements.text: Good morning! Wanted to get some insight from fellow marketers on something. We've spent the past few months producing the first season of a new podcast and developed a campaign to coincide with its launch, which was scheduled for today. We decided over the weekend to pull the plug for the time being, as we felt it would have seemed tone deaf and trivial after the events of this weekend. We're trying to figure out the right way to approach it now. I'm curious to hear how others are handling similar situations this week.

text: same here. one thing to think about is more specific communication with customers and prospects who might benefit from the podcast instead of pulling the plug completely.

elements.text: same here. one thing to think about is more specific communication with customers and prospects who might benefit from the podcast instead of pulling the plug completely.

text:
Morning! I think noticing that an effort seems tone deaf, even a little unimportant, given circumstances, is a big first step. So kudos to you and your team.

We had to do something similar for a big report and corresponding campaign when COVID hit (the report was about how unemployment was super low at the time). We also pulled plans to go live, then we worked to incorporate new survey questions and promotional material based on our customer needs and environment. Even though we kept some parts of the report and promo plan around hiring, we shifted a lot and made it about taking care of your employees and team, and how to bring humanity into big strategic decisions.

It really worked for us. If your company/team is open to it, I wouldn't be afraid to ask how these times are affecting your team and your customers and work hard to be responsive and agile, which could look like scheduling impromptu podcast guests, or re-working the podcast focus to reflect what's important to your company and customers right now.

elements.text:
Morning! I think noticing that an effort seems tone deaf, even a little unimportant, given circumstances, is a big first step. So kudos to you and your team.

We had to do something similar for a big report and corresponding campaign when COVID hit (the report was about how unemployment was super low at the time). We also pulled plans to go live, then we worked to incorporate new survey questions and promotional material based on our customer needs and environment. Even though we kept some parts of the report and promo plan around hiring, we shifted a lot and made it about taking care of your employees and team, and how to bring humanity into big strategic decisions.

It really worked for us. If your company/team is open to it, I wouldn't be afraid to ask how these times are affecting your team and your customers and work hard to be responsive and agile, which could look like scheduling impromptu podcast guests, or re-working the podcast focus to reflect what's important to your company and customers right now.

text: Thanks for sharing that, Ashly! That's very helpful. My wheels have been turning on this, because the podcast itself is on overcoming adversity. I think that message has an opportunity to be impactful and relevant with the right context and timing. That timing just isn't today.

elements.text: Thanks for sharing that, Ashly! That's very helpful. My wheels have been turning on this, because the podcast itself is on overcoming adversity. I think that message has an opportunity to be impactful and relevant with the right context and timing. That timing just isn't today.

text:
Oh, wow! What a timely topic, <@UUVC19ZE0> . Your instincts sound spot-on. Every situation is so different, but we ended up postponing the publication of our report and campaign about a month because that was the time it took to really survey, talk about, and form an authentic response with our team and with our customers.

It also helped that our leadership team was on-board for changing the "metrics of success" and original goals of the campaign. Thankfully, it was never intended to be a huge demand-gen effort - it was more of a brand awareness/education push - but even so, everyone agreed that trying to get hot leads from these efforts was no longer the biggest priority. I think that was key for us. Good luck, and I have no doubt it will be a helpful campaign when the time is right!

elements.text: Oh, wow! What a timely topic,

. Your instincts sound spot-on. Every situation is so different, but we ended up postponing the publication of our report and campaign about a month because that was the time it took to really survey, talk about, and form an authentic response with our team and with our customers.

It also helped that our leadership team was on-board for changing the "metrics of success" and original goals of the campaign. Thankfully, it was never intended to be a huge demand-gen effort - it was more of a brand awareness/education push - but even so, everyone agreed that trying to get hot leads from these efforts was no longer the biggest priority. I think that was key for us. Good luck, and I have no doubt it will be a helpful campaign when the time is right!

text:
Given current events, how/are your teams adjusting your content or social publishing this week? 

Our social team stopped publishing over the weekend and we’re holding off on all content (both “brand” and SEO) for the moment. I am curious how other SaaS/b2b companies are approaching right now, what questions you ask yourself, etc.

elements.text:
Given current events, how/are your teams adjusting your content or social publishing this week? 

Our social team stopped publishing over the weekend and we’re holding off on all content (both “brand” and SEO) for the moment. I am curious how other SaaS/b2b companies are approaching right now, what questions you ask yourself, etc.

text: I’m definitely avoiding super “happy” or “braggy” brandy content, like behind the scenes employee or customer photos, awards, etc.

text:
The goal is allyship.

Running your business into the ground and martyring yourself (similar to what some folks recommended others do during COVID)...

is NOT being an ally.

You can still sell and market without being tone deaf.

This isn't binary.

elements.text:
The goal is allyship.

Running your business into the ground and martyring yourself (similar to what some folks recommended others do during COVID)...

is NOT being an ally.

You can still sell and market without being tone deaf.

This isn't binary.

text: We also paused social posting for now... But publishing blog content/emails to users that are still registering/upgrading hasn't changed. I think it's okay to err on the side of caution on social media just to see how things go for a bit!

elements.text: We also paused social posting for now... But publishing blog content/emails to users that are still registering/upgrading hasn't changed. I think it's okay to err on the side of caution on social media just to see how things go for a bit!

text: Definitely a very chaotic and sensitive time... And agree with Cassandra. Avoiding any "look at the cool stuff we do!" type posts would be a good start :+1::skin-tone-3:

elements.text: Definitely a very chaotic and sensitive time... And agree with Cassandra. Avoiding any "look at the cool stuff we do!" type posts would be a good start

text:
Thanks all for sharing. 

Agree that it isn’t binary. This is our approach today, not forever. However, relevance and audience state of mind is always top of mind and there are dozens/hundreds of folks who have our blog set up to publish to their social feeds via RSS, which we keep in mind when it comes to publishing. 

With COVID we didn’t pause any SEO content, just used that lens to ensure it felt applicable, and we updated our brand calendar to replace with helpful content speaking directly to the situation. As an organization, championing DEI is one of our core values and something our team feels strongly about—I don’t think it’s martyrdom to take a beat and reflect on how/whether we should speak to the current situation.

elements.text:
Thanks all for sharing. 

Agree that it isn’t binary. This is our approach today, not forever. However, relevance and audience state of mind is always top of mind and there are dozens/hundreds of folks who have our blog set up to publish to their social feeds via RSS, which we keep in mind when it comes to publishing.

With COVID we didn’t pause any SEO content, just used that lens to ensure it felt applicable, and we updated our brand calendar to replace with helpful content speaking directly to the situation. As an organization, championing DEI is one of our core values and something our team feels strongly about—I don’t think it’s martyrdom to take a beat and reflect on how/whether we should speak to the current situation.

text: While I agree that allyship is great, what I’m seeing is more _performative_ allyship and I’m trying to avoid that. If you’re posting stuff on social media about being an ally before your company has spoken with employees, at the very least, and ideally actually become a safe space for black people to work…

elements.text: While I agree that allyship is great, what I’m seeing is more
performative

allyship and I’m trying to avoid that. If you’re posting stuff on social media about being an ally before your company has spoken with employees, at the very least, and ideally actually become a safe space for black people to work…

text: That is not helpful.

elements.text: That is not helpful.

text: Honestly that is not something that can just happen overnight in tandem with these protests. And if we’re being real honest with ourselves, I think we know that _most_ tech companies are not safe spaces for black people to work.

elements.text: Honestly that is not something that can just happen overnight in tandem with these protests. And if we’re being real honest with ourselves, I think we know that

tech companies are not safe spaces for black people to work.

text:
<@U010282SFBL> Didn't watch the video, but read your post on that last week!

Do you mean lead scoring?

At a former co, we had verrrrrryyy long sales cycle for $1M+ contracts. One of the ways we tracked interest was by tagging sales collateral/decks with tracking codes via Pardot to see who clicked on what or showed interest in what.

Their lead score increased/decreased based on those actions (or lack thereof)
